Puerto Real 11510 Cádiz Spain Graphical abstract Copper-iron mixed oxides with Fe/Cu molar ratios ranging from pure CuO to Fe2O3 were synthesised by a low temperature co-precipitation method, and tested in the CO-PROX reaction. The extensive characterization performed by means of different techniques showed the progressive variation of physical and chemical properties including composition, texture, structure and reducibility of the prepared oxides. Rietveld analysis of X-ray diffraction data, XPS and Raman spectra, and especially TEM study revealed the formation of CuFe2O4. All the samples were more active and selective below 200 °C than a commercial Pt/Al2O3 catalyst used as a reference. In particular, the catalyst having a 2 Fe/Cu molar ratio, corresponding to the cuprospinel stoichiometry, exhibited the best performance with a 76% conversion and a 60% selectivity at 125 °C, operating with 50% of H2 in the gas stream, being relatively stable in long-term time-on-stream experiments. On the contrary, pure CuO rapidly deactivated in the course of reaction at 150 °C. Differences in catalytic stability were related to a promoting effect of iron in the mixed oxide which makes copper more resistant to full reduction. Keywords Cu-Fe mixed oxide CO oxidation CuFe2O4 PROX catalyst Low temperature synthesis 1 Introduction Hydrogen utilization in polymeric electrolyte membrane (PEM) fuel-cells has forced the development of new catalysts which are able to reduce the CO content in H2-rich streams below 100 ppm, using for that the well-known CO-PROX (preferential oxidation of CO in the presence of hydrogen) process [1]. Recently Cu-Fe-Ce mixed oxides have been proposed for CO-PROX reaction [2–4] as alternative to the extensively used noble metal-based catalysts [5–7]. Such oxides exhibit activity comparable to those of Pt and Au [8]. In addition, they are more selective, cheaper and less sensitive to deactivation by sulphides. However, it should be noticed that these oxides are usually synthesized by conventional co-precipitation methods which imply final stages of calcination at high temperatures, sometimes well above 500 °C [9–12]. Cu-Fe mixed oxides have been also previously reported as good catalysts for water gas shift reaction [10,13], alcohol synthesis by CO hydrogenation [11,14] and even oxidations in liquid phase [15]. Nevertheless, to our knowledge, studies dealing with their application in CO-PROX are still relatively scarce [16]. In the above context, the aim of this work was to prepare mixed oxides which are just composed of copper and iron, as they are even cheaper than those currently employed. Moreover, for their synthesis a simple co-precipitation method which allows obtaining catalytically active samples without requiring the final calcination step, that typically decreases the specific surface area, has been followed. The so-prepared oxides were further tested in the CO-PROX reaction with special attention being paid to the influence of the Fe/Cu molar ratio used in the preparation. For comparative purposes, CuO and Fe2O3 samples prepared using the same methodology of synthesis here proposed, and a commercial Pt/Al2O3 catalyst for the catalytic study, were also investigated. The latter was selected considering that supported Pt group metals have been extensively proposed as reference catalysts for this reaction [17–19]. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts synthesis and reference materials In this work five different copper-iron mixed oxides with nominal Fe/Cu molar ratios of 0.05, 0.4, 1, 2 and 3, together with pure CuO and Fe2O3, were prepared. Hereafter the notation used for the mixed oxide samples is referred to such ratio, i.e. CuFe0.4Ox is a sample prepared so as to contain 0.4 moles of Fe per mole of Cu. The followed experimental procedure was similar to that previously employed to prepare Cu-Al mixed oxides [20]. Briefly, a solution of Na2CO3 and NaOH in water was dropped over another aqueous solution containing amounts of CuCl2 and FeCl3∙6H2O which were adjusted according to the final desired stoichiometry [15]. The resulting dark brown suspension was stirred at 70 °C for 22 h, filtered and washed with boiled water, being further dried in stove at 125 °C for 24 h. The final material was crushed and exposed to air for 3 days. The commercial Pt/Al2O3 sample used as a reference for the catalytic tests was provided by Micromeritics having a metal loading of 0.5 wt% and a platinum dispersion of 32% as measured by means of CO volumetric adsorption. In the particular case of the synthetized CuFe2Ox mixed oxide, another reference sample for the catalytic study was also prepared by adding a treatment that consisted in submitting the just dried sample to a final calcination at 500 °C for 3 h. 2.2 Characterization techniques The catalysts prepared by the indicated procedure were characterized by means of a wide battery of techniques such as N2 physisorption, granulometry, X-Ray Diffraction (XRD), chemical analysis by Inductively Coupled Plasma (ICP) and X-Ray Fluorescence (XRF), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) with Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS), Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA), Temperature-Programmed Reduction (TPR), X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS), Raman spectroscopy and Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM). Textural characterization of the samples was carried out by measuring the adsorption/desorption of N2 at −196 °C, employing both Micromeritics ASAP 2020 and Autosorb IQ (Quantachrome) devices. Prior to analysis, all the samples were degassed for 2 h at 150 °C under vacuum. The obtained isotherms were used to calculate the specific surface area (SBET) as well as the porosity features of the studied samples. The granulometric study was carried out using a Mastersizer 2000 granulometer from Malvern, operating with laser diffraction and previous ultrasonication of the samples in deionised water during 5 min. To ensure reproducibility of the measurements, results were obtained in each case as the average of three independent runs. XRD studies were carried out in a BRUKER D8 ADVANCE 500 powder diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 40 mA). The diagrams were recorded in the 2θ angle range from 3° to 75°, using a step size of 0.05° and a counting time of 18 s. For a Rietveld refined analysis of the data, the Fullprof programme was used [21]. ICP analysis of the chemical composition was performed using an IRIS Intrepid HR instrument. Also, XRF analysis in a Bruker S4 Pioneer spectrometer was carried out for the same purpose. SEM images and EDS compositional data were obtained using a QUANTA-200 scanning electron microscope equipped with a Phoenix microanalysis system with nominal resolution of 3 nm. In addition, EDS maps corresponding to the distribution of Cu, Fe and O were recorded in a Field Emission Gun (FEG) scanning electron microscope (Nova NanoSEM 450) equipped with an EDAX system and operating below 30 kV. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out in a Shimadzu TGA-60 thermobalance, with a constant heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under an air flow (100 ml min−1) until 900 °C. About 50 mg of each sample were used for each experiment. XPS analyses were carried out with a Kratos Axis UltraDLD instrument, equipped with monochromatised Al Kα (hʋ = 1486.6 eV) radiation at a pass energy of 80 eV. X-ray power was set to 150 W and the analysis area was 300 × 700 μm. Analysis of XPS data was performed by using the CasaXPS (2.3.18) software. The temperature-programmed reduction studies were performed in an experimental device coupled to a TCD detector Autochem Micromeritics apparatus. The amount of sample routinely used in these experiments was 30 mg, the 5% H2/Ar flow rate was 25 ml min−1, and the heating ramp was 10 °C min−1. Prior to all the TPR runs the samples were cleaned by heating them under flowing He at 25 ml min−1, at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1, up to 150 °C; then, they were kept for 1 h at this temperature and cooled down to room temperature. TPR of selected post-reaction catalysts was performed in an experimental device coupled to a quadrupole mass spectrometer, Pfeiffer, model QSM 200 D-35614. Raman spectra of the samples were measured at 1 cm−1 resolution using a dispersive Raman spectrometer (Jasco, model NRS7200) with a 100X objective coupled to a 532 nm Nd-YAG laser excitation source. Care was taken to avoid heat-induced phase changes in the samples. Laser power was set at 0.7 mW in such a way that laser intensity on the samples was reduced down to 0.01 mW μm−2. Raman spectra were collected for 60 s. Finally, TEM and HREM studies were performed in a scanning–transmission JEOL2010F electron microscope, working at 200 kV. This instrument, with a Field Emission Gun (FEG), has a structural resolution of 0.19 nm. It is equipped with a scanning unit and a high angle annular dark field detector, which enables for HAADF-(S)TEM imaging mode, also called (Z-contrast imaging), and an Oxford SDD X-Ray Energy Dispersive (EDX) detector X-Max 80 system. Taking into account the elemental composition of the material under study, in particular to detect and quantify Cu from our samples, we used a holy Carbon Au-grid in combination with a Beryllium-type analytical TEM specimen holder from Gatan Inc. These experimental conditions enabled minimizing unwanted Cu X-Ray signals from the sample preparation and TEM studies. 2.3 Catalytic tests Catalytic activity tests were performed in a quartz fixed-bed reactor at atmospheric pressure. Prior to each test, the catalysts were treated in He flow (60 ml min−1) at 150 °C for 1 h. Analysis of both inlet and outlet reaction mixtures was accomplished by using a gas chromatograph analyser (Bruker 450-GC). The mass of catalyst used in the experiments was 50 mg diluted with 100 mg of SiC, and the mixture of gases was composed of 50% H2, 1% O2, 1% CO and He in balance with a flow of 100 ml min−1. The CO conversion, and the selectivity (%) to CO2 were obtained as follows: (1) C O c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = ( C O ) i n − ( C O ) o u t ( C O ) i n × 100 (2) S e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = C O c o n v e r s i o n 2 x O 2 c o n v e r s i o n × 100 where the O2 conversion is calculated similarly to the CO conversion considering in that case the O2 concentration at the inlet and outlet of the reactor. Complementary stability tests at 150 °C for 21 h were carried out using the above mentioned conditions. In the particular case of the CuFe2Ox sample, this test was monitored up to 80 h of time-on-stream. Additionally an experiment followed by mass spectrometry (Pfeiffer, model QSM 200 D-35614) was carried out for the CuO sample, monitoring the evolution of the species involved in the PROX reaction and using 50 mg of catalyst and 25% H2, 0.5% O2, 0.5% CO and He in balance (100 ml min−1) as feedstock. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Chemical composition Table 1 summarizes the results obtained in the chemical analysis of the samples investigated in this work. An inspection of the data shows two noteworthy features. First, notice how, in general, there is a good agreement in the elemental content determined using different techniques such as ICP, XRF and SEM-EDS. Moreover, the use of a surface sensitive technique such as XPS reveals that the samples surface Fe and Cu content are in the order of their massive composition. And second, when such content is expressed as molar ratio, it leads to empiric formulae that match quite well with the nominal composition values selected for the preparation. In addition, it should be noticed that the amount of chlorine detected by XRF, EDS and XPS analyses was negligible in spite of having started from chlorides as precursors. This proves the efficiency of the washing step in the preparation of the oxides. Elemental distribution maps were also recorded from the EDS analysis. Fig. 1 shows those corresponding to the CuFe2Ox sample taken as representative. As can be seen the three elements (Cu, Fe and O) seem to be distributed homogeneously over the surface and in a similar way. No significant differences were observed between them suggesting that no segregation effects occurred and a mixed oxide was formed as desired. Similar results were obtained for the rest of copper-iron mixed oxides studied (Supplementary material, Fig. S1 and 2). 3.2 Textural properties Fig. 2 shows the N2 physisorption isotherms recorded for all the mixed oxides samples to illustrate the influence of the Fe/Cu ratio. Those corresponding to the CuO and Fe2O3 references samples are included in the Supplementary material (Fig. S3). As can be noticed, the CuFe0.05Ox sample exhibited a type II isotherm with H3 hysteresis loop characteristic of macroporous solids [22]. For the rest of the samples, as iron content grew the isotherms presented an increasing type IV character typical of mesoporous solids, with a hysteresis loop that changed from H1 to H2 type [22]. Processing of the above isotherms leaded to the pore size distribution curves also included in Fig. 2 and data collected in Table 2 . It is remarkable that the specific surface area increased with the iron content, reaching a maximum of nearly 300 m2/g for the CuFe2Ox sample. It should be also noticed that, although all the samples were basically mesoporous, the presence of some micropores cannot be completely discarded considering the low average pore diameter values estimated for some of the studied oxides. General evolution of the surface area with the composition was also consistent with the results obtained by thermogravimetric analysis (Supplementary material, Fig. S4). Weight loss of the studied copper-iron mixed oxides upon heating under air increased with their corresponding surface area, mostly taking place below 100 °C which could be reasonably related with their relative humidity content. To enhance the textural characterization of the samples they were also observed by SEM. Fig. 3 shows an illustrative selection of the obtained images, the rest being included in the Supplementary material (Fig. S5). As can be seen, the prepared oxides exhibited an irregular morphology, both in form and size. This was confirmed by a complementary study through granulometry (Supplementary material, Fig. S6) which revealed a heterogeneous particle size distribution, different for each of the mixed oxides prepared, and ranging from very fine (0.2 μm) to quite large (above 100 μm) grains. 3.3 Structural characterization X-ray diffractograms corresponding to a representative selection of the prepared mixed oxides are shown in Fig. 4 . A simple perusal of the diagrams allows assigning the main features to the well-known and reported CuO tenorite phase (JCPDS 48-1548). In order to understand how iron is present in the samples, we performed a more detailed analysis of the XRD diagrams using the Rietveld method. In the case of the mixed oxide having the lowest iron content only CuO (tenorite) phase could be identified. On the other hand, for samples with higher amount of iron the simulation of the experimental spectra gave the best fitting upon considering a cuprospinel (CuFe2O4) phase, its relative proportion respect to CuO increasing with the Fe content. As an example, Fig. 5 shows the Rietveld analysis carried out for the CuFe0.4Ox, CuFe2Ox and CuFe3Ox samples. Along with the main presence of CuO and CuFe2O4 phases, other minority phases such as FeOOH lepidocrocite, Cu3(CO3)2(OH)2 azurite and Cu2CO3(OH)2 malachite were considered. Although these phases were tentatively included to improve the adjustment, their presence is consistent with the thermogravimetric curves above mentioned (Fig. S4) that showed small weight losses at moderate and high temperatures which could be reasonably attributed to the decomposition of oxohydroxydes and hydroxycarbonates, respectively. It is also worthy of comment the evolution of the majority phases with the sample composition. As can be observed in Fig. 4, the intensity of the CuO peaks decreases with the increase of iron content. This effect can be reasonably interpreted as an indication that the greater Fe content, the greater amount of Cu involved in the CuFe2O4 synthesis and the lesser related to the tenorite formation. By the other hand, although the amount of CuFe2O4 formed increases with Fe content, the known effect of the Fe fluorescence with Cu K-alpha radiation might prevent the observation of peaks related to the iron-containing phase. In addition, the high BET surface area values (>200 m2/g) of the samples with high iron content suggest that the spinel particles are composed of very small sized crystals, which would also contribute to their difficult detection. This interpretation will be supported by TEM measurements (see below). A complementary study using Raman spectroscopy was also performed. Fig. 6 shows the Raman spectra recorded for all the samples here studied. The Raman band of the CuO oxide occurring at 296 cm−1 [23] and the band of the α-Fe2O3 phase occurring at 292 cm−1 [24] were both present in all the mixed oxide samples under study, as a convolution of them. It is worth noting the presence of the CuO oxide bands at 347 cm−1 and 636 cm−1 [23], which held in the samples even with high iron content. It should be also highlighted the occurrence of Raman bands at around 675 cm−1 and 704 cm−1, which have been ascribed to the magnetite (Fe3O4) and cuprospinel (CuFe2O4) spinel phases, respectively [25]. In order to better confirm the presence of the CuFe2O4, (S)TEM studies were performed for the CuFe2Ox sample, in which the experimental composition (Table 1) resulted to be the closest one to the nominal cuprospinel stoichiometry. Fig. 7 shows representative electron transmission micrographs from these studies. As noticed, the CuFe2Ox sample is mainly constituted by large agglomerations (Fig.7a) of very smaller nanoparticles in the range of c.a. 2–10 nm (Fig.7b). In addition, a lower fraction of the material, which is composed by much larger crystallites with brighter contrast in the Z-contrast images, is also detected. Moreover, the compositional analysis performed by STEM-EDX studies indicated that the former is iron-rich, as expected for the CuFe2Ox formulation, while for the latter a Cu enrichment is found (see Supplementary material, Fig. S7). This last result suggests that the CuO phase detected by means of XRD and Raman studies, must likely concentrate in certain areas of the material. The analysis of Digital Diffraction Patterns (DDPs) of selected areas on the HREM images corresponding to the iron rich nanoparticles agglomerates unveiled the crystallographic nature of the main fraction of the CuFe2Ox sample. The DDP from a randomly selected crystallite (as inset of Fig. 7c) can be attributed to the CuFe2O4 structure, viewed along the [010] direction, with its corresponding {200} and {101} planes, with characteristic spacing, d, of 2.9 and 4.7 Å, respectively [26]. 3.4 Redox characterization Fig. 8 shows the TPR study of all the samples investigated. It is very evident that the TPR profiles evolved gradually with composition from the one typical of CuO, dominated by a broad H2 consumption peak with maximum around 265 °C [27,28], to that of Fe2O3 presenting three peaks, at 360, 560 (broad shoulder) and 760 °C (the most intense) which according to literature [29] might correspond to consecutive Fe2O3 → Fe3O4 → FeO → Fe bulk reduction processes, respectively. In any case, interpretation of the TPR curves is complex. In fact, the apparent single peak of CuO seems actually to be composed of two considering its asymmetry, which might be related to consecutive reduction to Cu2O and Cu. In this sense, notice how as the iron content increased this peak clearly splitted into two, both shifting to lower temperature, what might be indicative of the formation of a copper-iron mixed oxide in which the interaction between both metals might render more reducible the copper ions. At the same time a very broad band above 300 °C appeared, its relative intensity increasing in parallel to the decrease of the peaks already assigned to copper reduction, especially the one around 200 °C. The sum of both effects made the curve resemble each time more the one of pure Fe2O3. Moreover, there seems to be an optimum of the mixed oxide composition regarding the temperature at which reduction starts, this being even below 100 °C in the case of CuFe2Ox. Let’s recall that this is the sample that exhibited also the highest specific surface area and that was prepared with cuprospinel stoichiometry, whose formation was confirmed by the structural characterization. It should be also noticed that the TPR profile of this sample is very similar to that reported by Subramanian et al. for a nanosized CuFe2O4 synthesized by a sol-gel method with final calcination at 400 °C for 5 h [13]. With the aim to better understand the reducibility behaviour of the prepared oxides we proceeded to integrate the above TPR curves. The result can be found in Table 3 where position of peaks maxima has been also specified. Note that, although the total amount of H2 consumed was quite similar in all the samples, ranging from 10.6 mmol/g in the case of CuFe0.05Ox to 13.6 mmol/g for Fe2O3, the consumptions associated to each of the areas related to copper and iron phases changed gradually as a function of the composition (see data into brackets in Table 3). Moreover, taking into account data from the chemical analysis, shown in Table 1, these consumptions are consistent with the total reduction of copper and iron species originally present as Cu(II) and Fe(III). This also allows confirming the validity of the above interpretation of the obtained TPR profiles. Taking into account that TPR technique provides information about the bulk of the oxides, and that from the catalytic point of view the analysis of the outer surface is particularly relevant in order to know the nature and redox state of the species that can be active for the reaction, we also performed a complementary study by means of XPS. Fig. 9 shows the Cu 2p and Fe 2p regions of the XPS spectra recorded for some of the samples here investigated. The Fe 2p signal consisted of two peaks, Fe 2p1/2 and Fe 2p3/2. Moreover, the latter (the main one) could be deconvoluted in two contributions. The binding energy peaks at 711.4, 711.2 and 710.9 eV (in green colour) for CuFe0.4Ox, CuFe2Ox and CuFe3Ox respectively could be assigned to Fe(III), and those at 709.4, 709.1 and 708.9 eV (red coloured) could be assigned to Fe(II) [30]. Other authors who studied Cu-Fe-based mixed oxides also detected both types of iron species on the surface employing XPS [31,32]. In our work, the presence of more reduced iron species, located at the outer surface of the samples, might be tentatively related to the Fe3O4 phase detected by Raman spectroscopy. In any case, the Fe(II) species must play a minor role from a quantitative viewpoint, if we recall the TPR results previously discussed. Regarding the Cu 2p signal (also included in Fig. 9), it consisted of two peaks, Cu 2p1/2 and Cu 2p3/2, and their respective satellite features located at higher binding energy. As the related bibliography points out that the interpretation of these signals is quite complex, the XPS spectrum of the CuO sample was also recorded as a reference (Supplementary material, Fig. S8). In this case, the most intense peak (Cu 2p3/2) was relatively symmetric and centred at 933.5 eV. Both this position and its relative intensity compared with that of its shake-up satellite [33] are those characteristic of CuO tenorite [34,35]. In the case of the CuFe0.4Ox and CuFe2Ox mixed oxides (Fig. 9) a similar ratio between the intensities of the satellite contribution and the main peak was found what allows its assignment also to Cu(II) species. However, it is shifted to lower binding energy (932.0 eV) denoting the coexistence of more reduced copper species. Other authors [31] found a similar effect in samples in which the CuFe2O4 spinel phase had been detected by XRD. This interpretation cannot be adopted for the CuFe3Ox sample due to both the lower relative intensity of the Cu 2p3/2 satellite and the asymmetry of its main peak. Therefore a deconvolution was performed in this case showing that the latter is the sum of two contributions, one located at 932.0 eV (orange trace) related to Cu(II) with a cuprospinel environment as above, and the second at 931.0 eV (blue line) that can be assigned either to Cu(I) or metallic copper [36,37]. 3.5 Catalytic activity Fig. 10 shows the conversion and selectivity curves obtained during the catalytic tests of the samples in the CO-PROX reaction. On the other hand, Table 4 summarizes the main data derived from these curves. According to these results, all the prepared oxides, except Fe2O3, exhibited the maximum CO conversion at lower temperature than the commercial Pt/Al2O3 sample. Also remarkable, for the CuFe2Ox, the sample having the cuprospinel nominal composition, 76% conversion was reached at only 125 °C. Moreover, this sample showed significant activity even since 100 °C. In terms of selectivity towards CO2, at their respective maximum conversion temperatures, CuFe2Ox was also the most selective one, while the highest selectivity value of each prepared oxide was higher than the one of the Pt/Al2O3 reference, which showed a selectivity value around 50% in the whole range of studied temperatures. It is noteworthy that when the CuFe2Ox mixed oxide was submitted to a calcination treatment (500 °C, 3 h) as final stage of its synthesis, it exhibited lower conversion and selectivity even at higher reaction temperature (Table 4). This calcination treatment was chosen as representative of the conventional final steps in the preparation of Cu-Fe mixed oxides for similar catalytic uses [12]. Therefore, the just mentioned results demonstrate the advantages of the low temperature synthesis here proposed. The above results contrast with those obtained in previous tests for the CO oxidation in the absence of H2 (Fig. 11 ). In that case CuO exhibited the best performance, the activity decreasing with the Fe content. On the contrary iron seems to act as a promoter of copper in the selective CO oxidation (in the presence of high H2 concentration) as a function of its content, the optimum being that corresponding to the cuprospinel. Furthermore, the best behaviour in general observed for this sample is consistent with the TPR study which showed the highest reducibility of CuFe2Ox. This certainly should be an advantage in the redox mechanism of the reaction, considering other studies in literature which suggested a Mar van Krevelen mechanism involving the participation of lattice oxygen in the CO-PROX reaction over copper-containing mixed oxides [38]. Regarding the comparison between the conversion and selectivity values obtained in this work and those previously reported in literature, this is undoubtedly a hard and risky task because most of the studies performed dealt either with noble metals or CuO-CeO2 catalysts [17]. In addition, one must be careful with variables such as the catalyst composition and other reaction conditions like gas stream nature, including the possible presence of CO2 and/or H2O. In this sense, our results should be rather compared with the scarce works reporting on Cu-Fe mixed oxides for CO-PROX. For example, in [16] the authors studied Cu-Fe mixed oxides but prepared by a higher temperature synthesis route, finding that they were more active than pure Fe2O3 and CuO. Our results are in good agreement with such observation. On the contrary, these authors did not find a clear correlation between catalytic activity and specific surface area, while in our case it was also favourable to the CuFe2Ox sample, the most active one. Concerning the maximum activity measured by these authors it corresponded to a sample showing a 100% conversion at 135 °C with 80% selectivity to CO2 at that temperature. These values are better than those of our CuFe2Ox but it must be considered that in our case much more severe conditions were applied for the CO-PROX reaction with 50% of H2 in the feedstock instead of 6% as employed in the cited work. A general revision of bibliography about preferential CO oxidation confirms that only few works report a durability test for this reaction [17]. However, the deactivation is a parameter of great importance for an industrial application that merits more research. So, we also studied the stability of the samples by performing long-term time-on-stream CO-PROX experiments at 150 °C. Fig. 12 collects the conversion and selectivity curves recorded in these tests as a function of time. As can be seen, the activity of all the tested Cu-Fe mixed oxides kept quite stable for at least 21 h (conversion losses lower than 5%), contrarily to the CuO sample which deactivated very fast, losing more than 60% of its initial conversion capacity and selectivity after only 2 h. The stability shown by our Cu-Fe mixed oxides is also better than that recently reported for Co-promoted Pt/Al2O3 catalysts with remarkable performance which lost 20% of conversion in 20 h at 110 °C [18]. In the particular case of the CuFe2Ox sample, a longer experiment (80 h) was also performed, taking as a reference the study of Moretti et al. [39]. It was found that, between 20 and 80 h, the catalyst lost an extra 13% of its conversion and selectivity, results that are still better than those above mentioned [18]. In relation to the causes of deactivation in this reaction some authors have pointed to the blocking of the active sites at the catalyst surface by water as a factor that may play a key role [16]. On the other hand, working with copper-based oxides other authors proposed that Cu(I) species could be the active sites, their reduction to metallic copper being the origin of deactivation observed in that type of catalysts [40]. In this context, we recorded Raman spectra of the CuO and CuFe2Ox samples after reaction to understand the cause for the strong deactivation observed in the former. As can be seen in Fig. 6, the original spectra changed in both samples after the catalytic tests. A general decrease of the intensity of the bands was recorded, this being particularly significant for those attributed to CuO. This suggests a partial reduction of the Cu(II) ions, most likely to the non-active in Raman Cu(0), although formation of Cu(I) cannot be completely discarded in the CuFe2Ox sample considering the observations by other authors who detected CuFeO2 delafossite phase on the surface of a post-reaction Cu-Fe mixed oxide [16] and that this is one of the stable compounds in the Cu-Fe-O ternary system [41]. This also might explain the stability of this sample, taking into account that the most active Cu(I) could compensate the least active Cu(0). In order to discriminate the influence of the two commented parameters, water formation and copper redox state changes, the CuO and CuFe2Ox samples that had been submitted to the stability tests were further studied by TPR. As can be seen in Fig. 13 , the modification of the TPR profiles is consistent with that of Raman spectra above commented. In both cases, there is a significant change respect to the fresh samples. For the CuO this change mainly consists of a significant decrease of the intensity of the peak centred approx. at 270 °C, which denotes the disappearance of oxidized copper species, most likely to Cu(0) considering the similarity between both profiles. In fact, integration of the areas suggests that only 42% of oxidized copper species remained after the reaction for 21 h. On the other hand, for the CuFe2Ox sample the first peak, attributed to reduction of Cu(II) to Cu(I) ions, practically disappeared while the second one, related to further reduction of the latter to Cu(0), became less intense and shifted to higher temperature. The changes of the wide asymmetric band at high temperatures that must correspond to iron species were much slighter. Moreover, total area of the peaks corresponding to copper in the fresh sample just diminished down to 80% in this post-reaction sample. This effect suggests that Cu(I) are the majority species remaining after the reaction and that they are more resistant to further reduction in the mixed oxide. This might contribute to the higher catalytic stability of this sample. Finally, we paid attention to the parallel evolution of the CO conversion and the signals corresponding to the species involved in the PROX reaction that were recorded by mass spectrometry while running the catalytic test over the CuO sample (Fig. 14 ). This analysis provided useful complementary information as indicates that: a) the catalyst is initially selective to CO2 formation; b) under the reaction conditions at 150 °C catalytst reduction takes place rendering a quick and intense H2O production; c) once the CuO has been partially reduced the water signal keeps being intense due to the parallel undesired reaction (H2 oxidation). This increase in the selectivity to water production is consistent with the strong decrease of selectivity to CO2 after 150 °C observed in Fig. 10; and d) after the sample is outgassed under inert flow in order to desorb the water, the initial activity is not significantly recovered which suggests that the reduction of copper caused an irreversible deactivation while the adsorption of water on the active sites over the surface could not play a significant role in the studied experimental conditions. 4 Conclusions In this work Cu-Fe mixed oxides with controlled composition in the whole range from CuO to Fe2O3 were prepared by a co-precipitation method that did not require final treatment at high temperature. The iron content modulated the general properties of the mixed oxides finding an optimum in terms of BET surface area and lattice oxygen mobility for a Fe/Cu molar ration equal to two. Not only for this composition but also for others the presence of the CuFe2O4 phase was suggested by XRD, XPS and Raman spectroscopies, its crystalline nanosized structure being confirmed by TEM. All the mixed oxides showed a good performance in the CO-PROX reaction compared to a commercial Pt/Al2O3 catalysts used as a reference. In particular, the one having composition corresponding to the cuprospinel exhibited the best behaviour with a conversion of 76% and a selectivity to CO2 of 60% at only 125 °C. Moreover, it was quite stable in experiments of long duration (21 h) like other Cu-Fe mixed oxides and in contrast to pure CuO which suffered fast deactivation. TPR studies of post-reaction samples, monitoring of species concentration by mass spectrometry in the course of reaction and running of a second cycle after evacuation under inert gas, indicated that changes in the redox state of copper rather than water adsorption on the surface were the major cause of activity depletion in CuO. On the contrary, iron may act as a promotor in the mixed oxides by increasing resistance of copper to full reduction, so retarding formation of non-active Cu(0) species. coredata.dc:description: Copper-iron mixed oxides with Fe/Cu molar ratios ranging from pure CuO to Fe2O3 were synthesised by a low temperature co-precipitation method, and tested in the CO-PROX reaction. The extensive characterization performed by means of different techniques showed the progressive variation of physical and chemical properties including composition, texture, structure and reducibility of the prepared oxides. Rietveld analysis of X-ray diffraction data, XPS and Raman spectra, and especially TEM study revealed the formation of CuFe2O4. All the samples were more active and selective below 200 °C than a commercial Pt/Al2O3 catalyst used as a reference. In particular, the catalyst having a 2 Fe/Cu molar ratio, corresponding to the cuprospinel stoichiometry, exhibited the best performance with a 76% conversion and a 60% selectivity at 125 °C, operating with 50% of H2 in the gas stream, being relatively stable in long-term time-on-stream experiments. On the contrary, pure CuO rapidly deactivated in the course of reaction at 150 °C. Differences in catalytic stability were related to a promoting effect of iron in the mixed oxide which makes copper more resistant to full reduction.
